headline: Nov. 19, 2025 Update on City Hall Campus Redevelopment
content: At the November 17 and 18 City Council meetings, City staff, along with representatives from Terra & Frisbie Group and CBRE, the City’s real estate consultant for the project, presented on the following areas of the project (click on the tabs below). The new conceptual plan proposes that all property west of NW 2nd Avenue remains City-owned and designated for public, civic, and recreational uses: The area identified for potential private development consists of 7.72 acres east of NW 2nd Avenue near the Brightline station, with plans for residential, retail, commercial, and hotel uses: CBRE presented the financial analysis for the City Hall Campus Master Plan. As part of the proposed project, the City would lease 7.72 acres east of NW 2nd Avenue to Terra & Frisbie Group for 99-years. In exchange, the City would receive annual rent, tax revenue, and new public facilities. Estimated Financial Benefit: Over the course of the 99-year lease, total revenue is projected to exceed $4.1 billion. When adjusted to reflect today’s value (accounting for inflation and risk using a 4.5% discount rate), this equates to a net financial benefit of approximately $353.8 million. Cost of Public Improvements: The estimated budget to build the new government campus facilities on the west side of the site is $198.99 million. *The cost estimates for the public facilities are benchmarked against similar recent public projects in other Florida cities. Learn more about how the numbers were estimated by viewing the presentation (page 10). Additional analyses currently underway. December 2, 2025: City Council Meeting December 16, 2025: City Council Meeting December 18, 2025: Planning & Zoning Board Meeting January 6, 2026: City Council Meeting January 20, 2026: City Council Meeting March 10, 2026: Municipal Election The proposed City Hall Campus redevelopment project is a long-term initiative and priority of City Council, aimed at addressing aging infrastructure and enhancing services for our growing community. Through a public-private partnership, this project will revitalize the area by modernizing City Hall services, which are currently housed in outdated facilities, and relocating and improving recreational amenities. The vision is to create a vibrant, mixed-use civic hub that embodies a true “live, work, play” lifestyle. By integrating government services with residential, retail, and recreational spaces, the redevelopment will foster a dynamic, interconnected community. This project will transform the City Hall Campus into a modern urban center that supports both civic engagement and long-term growth. Discussions about a new Government Campus started around 2017. While some designs were presented to the City Council, the project didn’t move forward at that time. In recent years, the City has made redeveloping the City Hall Campus a priority. We understand and appreciate that residents care deeply about Boca Raton’s future and that meaningful discussion is part of what makes our community strong. However, some information circulating about current City projects and business has been incomplete or inaccurate. The following documents provide clear, factual information directly from the City about current projects, City business, initiatives and decisions. Many of these topics have already been discussed and addressed in public meetings, but we know not everyone can follow every update. Our goal is to make sure residents always have accurate information to form opinions based on facts. Click on a category below for information related to that topic. Questions? Please contact [email protected]. December 2, 2025: City Council Meeting December 16, 2025: City Council Meeting December 16, 2025: City Council Meeting December 18, 2025: Planning & Zoning Board Meeting January 6, 2026: City Council Meeting January 20, 2026: City Council Meeting March 10, 2026: Municipal Election A group of residents have submitted two petition efforts, one proposing an ordinance and one proposing a Charter amendment, each containing identical language to restrict the City’s ability to lease or sell parcels of City-owned land larger than one-half acre (or any part thereof) without voter approval. At the October 28 meeting, City Council unanimously approved two resolutions placing those measures on the January 13, 2026, special election ballot. The proposed language reads: “The City Council shall not in any manner alienate from the public, lease or sell any land that is owned by the City of Boca Raton greater than one-half (0.5) acre, or any part thereof, except upon approval of the proposed action at a referendum election.” View the October 28 discussion from the beginning with staff updates. View the discussion related to the petitions and petition language. In March 2026, City of Boca Raton residents may see multiple ballot questions in relation to this project. Each question is different in scope and purpose. Here's what they mean: At the September 9 City Council Meeting, Council directed staff to prepare a referendum question to be placed on the March 10, 2025 Municipal Election Ballot about the proposed public-private partnership (P3) with Boca Raton City Center, LLC. (Terra & Frisbie Group). At the December 2, 2025 City Council Meeting, Council will review and consider the specific language related to this project. Visit Palm Beach County's Supervisor of Elections webpage for information about the upcoming elections. We value your input! Feedback provided by the community is being shared with City Council, staff and the developers as part of this process. Be sure to participate in helping to shape the future of Boca Raton’s downtown: Please note: As this process evolves, FAQs are updated regularly to ensure the community has access to the most accurate and current information.

headline: 'Tis the Season for the Holiday Street Parade
content: Come downtown and join us for the 53rd Annual Holiday Street Parade! This year's theme is The Centennial Express: 100 Years of Holiday Cheer and will be great fun for the entire family. Read some smart tips to #KnowBeforeYouGo. PLEASE NOTE: Federal Highway will be CLOSED to vehicular traffic from Glades Road to Camino Real starting at 5pm to approximately 11pm. The Holiday Street Parade will feature 60+ festive floats, community groups, marching bands and dance groups that will showcase the theme of The Centennial Express: 100 Years of Holiday Cheer, with music, songs and decorations for the entire community along Federal Highway in Downtown Boca. Date: Wednesday, December 3 Location: The parade starts at Federal Highway and SE 5th Street, and travels north to the Mizner Park Amphitheater. View the Parade Route Map. Weather: The parade will proceed rain or shine. Public Viewing Area: All along the parade route. Spectators must be on the sidewalk or median, and NOT in the street where parade will be traveling. Wheelchair accessible viewing areas can be located on the Parade Route Map. Safety Barricades: Temporary barricades will be placed along the parade route to ensure the safety of attendees and participants. All spectators must stay behind the barricades during the parade. Designated crosswalks will available along the route. Facility Closures: The Downtown Library and the Boca Raton Community Center will close at 5pm the day of the street parade. Food Vendors: Food for purchase will be available along the parade route, see the Parade Route Map for locations. Downtown Boca also features many restaurants nearby. Restrooms: Portable restrooms will be located along Federal Highway and near the viewing stands at Sanborn Square (72 N. Federal Hwy). See Parade Route Map for all locations. Have a Question?: Ask a City staff member. They will be in red "EVENT STAFF" shirts and can help you throughout the event. Run the Boca Holiday Mile: BEFORE the parade, participate in a family-friendly 1 mile "Boca Holiday Mile Run" with the Boca Raton Police Athletic League. Register online for the Holiday Run. HOW TO GET THERE AND WHERE TO PARK? The best places to park and how to arrive and depart safely. Road Closure: Arrive Early! Remember, Federal Highway will be CLOSED to vehicular traffic from Glades Road to Camino Real starting at 5pm to approximately 11pm. Free and ample parking available at: ٠ City Hall: 201 W. Palmetto Park Road ٠ Building Administration: 200 NW 2nd Avenue ٠ Downtown Public Library: 400 NW 2nd Avenue ٠ City Lot: 300 NW 2nd Avenue All metered parking spaces downtown will be available for FREE PARKING the night of the parade. Please note that all side streets along the parade route from Dixie Highway to Federal Highway will be blocked off. Hop on BocaConnect, the City’s easy and stress-free on-demand shuttle service. FREE and low-cost service in Downtown Boca and the surrounding area. Download the app and book your ride. Bicyclists: Bike racks are available in front of City Hall. Be sure to wear reflective clothing and add reflective material to your bike for safety. See Tracks? Think Train: For those walking to and from the event, look and listen before crossing any train tracks. Charge While You Attend: Electric car charging stations are available at City Hall and the Downtown Library. Plan Ahead: Whether you are utilizing a shared ride program or driving your car to the event, leave early and plan ahead in order to arrive to the event safe and on time. MORE THINGS TO DO IN DOWNTOWN BOCA Enjoy the holiday season and make it a night out on the town. Check out great places for happy hours, quick bites or fine dining, and places to go in Downtown Boca before or after the parade. Holiday Lights Downtown: From Royal Palm Place to Mizner Park, the holiday lights along the parade route are on full display. Take a stroll and enjoy them all on parade day, or on another night this holiday season. Plus, be sure to check out ALL the City's upcoming holiday events at www.myboca.us/bocajollydays. Let's Be Friends: Like Boca Raton Recreation on Facebook to stay updated on current and future City events. Spread the Love: Use the hashtag #LoveBocaRaton when posting your photos from the parade and other events. You might be featured on one of our social media pages! ٠ Subscribe to the City's monthly City Connection & to Recreation Service's The Boca Park Leaf ٠ Get the My Boca App for a quick and easy way to report a concern, check beach conditions, pay a water bill & more. ٠ Sign up TODAY to receive important messages about City services, initiatives, and emergency notifications directly from the City and Boca Raton Police Services through Alert Boca or text AlertBoca (no space) to 38276. SAFETY TIPS FROM POLICE & FIRE SERVICES Stay Alert: It takes four seconds or less for someone to break into your vehicle: Be sure to lock your car and take all personal items with you. Never leave your keys in your vehicle. Be Prepared: Talk to your family members about a potential meet up spot around the event in case you get separated. City of Boca Raton | 201 West Palmetto Park Road | Boca Raton, FL 33432 US Unsubscribe | Update Profile | Constant Contact Data Notice

headline: Boca Raton’s Centennial Comes Alive in Ode to Boca Mural
content: The City of Boca Raton has unveiled Ode to Boca, a vibrant new mural by local artist Brian Butler, now featured on the stage doors of the Mizner Park Amphitheater in celebration of the City’s Centennial. The mural reflects the stories, people, and experiences that have shaped Boca Raton over the past 100 years. Inspired by poems and reflections submitted through the City’s Ode to Boca initiative, the artwork blends community voices with Butler’s signature narrative style, creating a welcoming centerpiece in Downtown Boca. The mural depicts Boca Raton’s natural and cultural landmarks—from beaches and the Intracoastal Waterway to local wildlife and historic architecture—offering a layered visual story of the City’s past, present, and future. The project was revealed during a community celebration with remarks from City officials, a meet-and-greet with the artist, Poems on Demand by O, Miami, and displays of community-submitted verses. The Amphitheater’s stage doors are transformed into a large-scale expression of community storytelling, blending public art, poetry, and place. Inspired by local Odes to Boca, five- line poems from residents, business owners, and visitors about their personal connections to the City, the mural reflects Boca Raton’s collective voice — past, present, and future. Building on this outpouring of community expression, survey responses on the final artist’s vision statements also helped guide the direction of the project and the selection of the commissioned artist. South Florida artist Brian Butler brings a playful, narrative-driven style to this mural, with the artwork capturing a century of Boca Raton through signature architecture, beaches, and iconic local moments. Butler’s composition blends natural and cultural elements — a sunbather and sea turtle, a ship passing under the bridge, and memories of early Boca Raton alongside scenes of daily life today. It’s warm, restrained palette complements the surrounding downtown environment, and layered details invite visitors to explore the city’s history at both a glance and up close. Learn more about the Ode to Boca initiative, in partnership with O, Miami and submit YOUR Ode to Boca today.

headline: The Latest Economic Development News
content: In Boca Raton, economic development isn’t just about numbers — it’s about people, prosperity, and possibility. A thriving local economy drives innovation, strengthens our world-class infrastructure, and supports the exceptional quality of life that defines our community. The Office of Economic Development is here to help YOUR business. Read the latest insights on the City's business landscape and economic growth initiatives. The City’s Economic Development Incentives Policy helps attract and support corporate and regional headquarters by providing targeted grants that spur private investment, job creation, and long-term economic growth in Boca Raton. More Business Growth at BRiC CP Group, with DRA Advisors, announced over 266,000 SF of new and renewed leases at the Boca Raton Innovation Campus - a testament to Boca Raton’s strong and growing business climate. The activity spans technology, healthcare, education, and finance, including new leases from Allstar Recruiting Locums, Cinch Home Services, and EchoTwin AI, which relocated from San Francisco. As CP Group completes its $100 million modernization of BRiC, the campus continues to attract innovative companies and talent. Get Ready for the 2025 Bush's Boca Raton Bowl of Beans Back again this December, the Bush's Boca Raton Bowl of Beans brings national visibility, tourism, and economic impact to our community. As one of the City’s leading annual economic drivers, the event draws thousands of visitors, drives hotel and restaurant business, and showcases Boca Raton on a national stage through ESPN coverage. The City is proud to sponsor this signature event, highlighting the strong partnership between sports, business, and community in our region. Tuesday, December 23, 2PM. Stay tuned for ticket sales! Top Schools That Fuel Workforce Boca Raton’s A-rated schools continue to attract families and businesses, strengthening the City’s future talent pipeline. The Florida Department of Education named eight of the City's public schools as “Schools of Excellence,” and the FAU Lab Schools were recognized as a Cognia School of Distinction. With exceptional schools and higher education partners like Florida Atlantic University (now a top 100 public university!), Boca Raton offers both a skilled workforce and an outstanding quality of life. Boca Raton is making a strong case for corporate relocation from New York. A new Boyd Company report shows that New York City firms can save up to $7.5 million annually by relocating to Boca Raton, thanks to lower labor, real estate, and operating costs. With recent moves by The Farmer’s Dog and Innovative Solutions, and established headquarters like ADT and Celsius Holdings, Boca Raton continues to strengthen its position as a thriving corporate hub and driver of economic growth. Learn more about the comparison covered by [Your]News, Boca Raton Offers Companies $7.5 Million in Annual Savings Compared to New York City. Supply chain and logistics companies are increasingly turning to research parks and innovation districts for the talent, resources, and partnerships that accelerate growth. Read an article from the Office of Economic Development featured in Supply Chain Brain, on Why Logistics Companies Should Site Near Research and Innovation Centers. The Office of Economic Development recently awarded several grants through its Economic Development Incentives Policy, supporting new investment and job creation across the community. We’re proud to help spur new business in the City. See recent news about New Jersey based ADMA Biologics Inc's decision to relocate to Boca Raton, Why a Key U.S. Drug Supplier is Doubling Down on Boca Raton, and how BioStem Technologies Secures Land Purchase at the Research Park at Florida Atlantic University in Boca Raton for Future Headquarters. Plus, Centennial celebrations are in full swing in Boca Raton. Withum marked its first year in its new Boca Raton office with a community Open House which also honored the 100th anniversary of the City. Business and community leaders in attendance enjoyed networking and a special historical exhibit that underscored Withum’s growing presence and commitment to our local business community. Proactive Permitting: Accelerating Growth for Manufacturers A recent Manufacturing Journal from the City’s Economic Development Manager highlights how proactive permitting assistance can give manufacturers a competitive edge when expanding or relocating. Contact Neha James, the City of Boca Raton's Operations & Business Liaison Manager, to streamline your new commercial space, renovation or expansion. njames@bocaraton-fl.gov. More and more companies are expanding and investing in Boca Raton, recognizing it as the ideal place to grow and thrive. As our business community continues to evolve, we celebrate their success and the positive impact they bring to our local economy. Newcomers and expansions include: Boca Raton has long prioritized fostering a dynamic, business-friendly climate — and today’s forward-thinking initiatives continue to strengthen the City’s reputation as a hub for innovation and economic prosperity. Guident Leads Autonomous Shuttle Service in Mizner Park Boca Raton based Guident set to launch its autonomous shuttle service in Mizner Park on November 24. A pilot program for the City, this innovative project introduces a 0.6-mile autonomous shuttle loop, showcasing cutting-edge technology developed right here in Boca Raton. As a leader in autonomous vehicle monitoring and safety solutions, Guident’s local presence highlights the City’s reputation of fostering smart businesses and as a hub for sustainable mobility innovation. Expansion of the MiCa shuttle planned for Royal Palm Place. Boca Raton Earns LEED for Cities GOLD Certification The City has achieved the LEED for Cities Gold Certification from the U.S. Green Building Council (USGBC), joining an elite group of communities recognized for advancing sustainable growth and economic resilience. This milestone highlights Boca Raton’s commitment to building a future-ready economy that supports innovation, sustainability, and a high quality of life for businesses and residents alike. To learn more, contact Sustainability Manager Tina Batoh-Jennings at cbatohjennings@bocaraton-fl.gov. At recent City Council meetings, Terra & Frisbie Group provided a revised proposal to the City Hall Campus redevelopment project following additional community feedback. Learn more about the revised proposal, latest updates and project vision for this area of Downtown Boca. Boca Raton offers a diverse mix of corporate real estate — from expansive campuses and downtown hubs to historic landmarks, flexible office spaces, and vibrant live-work-play environments. Explore a selection of our premier corporate properties below. 2600 N. Military Trail Contact the Office of Economic Development today. Our team is ready to assist with corporate relocations, expansions, and other opportunities to grow your business in Boca Raton. Economic Development Manager economicdevelopment@bocaraton-fl.gov Miss our last 2025 bi-monthly report? To catch up on business in Boca Raton, read the latest Reports from the Office of Economic Development. Report #1 - September City of Boca Raton/Office of Economic Development17751 Boca Club Boulevard Boca Raton, FL 33487 US Unsubscribe | Update Profile | Constant Contact Data Notice

headline: Police Department Headquarters Information
content: As part of the March 10, 2026 election, City of Boca Raton voters will be asked to vote for or against a $175 million general obligation bond in order to construct a new Police Department Headquarters. This webpage provides background information, details of the proposed project, and financing facts to help residents make an informed decision. If you're interested in having City and Police Department representatives speak to your group about the Police Department Headquarters Referendum appearing on the March 2026 municipal ballot please fill out this form. The presentation is informational only and will provide a factual overview including background information, details of the proposed project, and financing facts to help residents make an informed decision. Boca Raton’s Police Department Headquarters was built nearly 40 years ago to serve a much smaller community. Since then, the City has expanded westward, grown in population, and become a hub for students, businesses, and visitors, shifting the population center and increasing service demands. The current headquarters located at 100 NW Boca Raton Blvd, is not hurricane-rated, does not currently provide enough space for all staff and equipment, has limited space for future expansion, and is not built to current standards. In 2007, a space needs study was conducted that identified options for an improved and expanded headquarters to meet the City's projected future public safety needs, prompting the project to be added into the City’s Capital Improvement Program. A new headquarters is being proposed at a site on Spanish River Blvd near I-95. If approved, this project will: *Note: The project will not inhibit the multi-use path around Blue Lake. On the March 10, 2026 ballot, City voters will be asked the following ballot question: Shall the City issue general obligation bonds, in one or more series, to finance the construction and equipping of a new police department headquarters, and related public safety support facilities located within the City in the principal amount not to exceed $175,000,000, bearing interest at not exceeding the legal rate, maturing not later than 30 years from the date of issuance, and payable from ad valorem taxes levied on all taxable property in the City? ________ FOR BONDS________ AGAINST BONDS The outcome of the referendum will determine whether the project moves forward. Election Day - Tuesday, March 10, 2026 Deadline to register to vote – Monday, February 9, 2026 Deadline to request that a VBM ballot be mailed to you - Thursday, February 26, 2026, by 5:00 p.m. Early Voting - Not available Deadline to return your VBM Ballot - Tuesday, March 10, 2026, by 7:00 p.m. to Main Office SOE office or by 5:00 p.m. to a Branch Office or Secure Ballot Intake Station Municipal Runoff Elections (if necessary) - Tuesday, March 24, 2026 More details can be found on the Palm Beach County Supervisor of Election's Office website.

headline: Sustainability Matters Newsletter Holiday Edition!
content: To read this newsletter in your browser, find it on the City's website. Dear Sustainability Champions, As we head into the holiday season, there’s much to be thankful for — and even more to celebrate when it comes to sustainability in Boca Raton! Over the past few months, our community has achieved several impressive milestones that highlight our shared commitment to protecting our environment and advancing the City’s sustainability goals. On October 27, the City proudly accepted its LEED for Cities Gold Certification, recognizing Boca Raton’s leadership in energy efficiency, waste reduction, innovation, and overall quality of life. Residents have also stepped up in meaningful ways: through the Unwrap the Waves program with Loggerhead Marinelife Center, we collected 11,550 Halloween candy wrappers citywide for recycling. Our Intracoastal Cleanup on November 6 brought together 21 volunteers, who paddled and walked along the shoreline of Rutherford Park to remove 109 pounds of trash and recyclables. Within this issue you’ll also find important information on how to green your holidays with sustainable tips — from reducing Thanksgiving food waste to curbing excessive gift purchases. I want to offer my sincerest thanks to our residents who continue to encourage and support the sustainability initiatives of our beautiful city. Your level of engagement is contagious and motivating, and I look forward to carrying that into the New Year. Until then, wishing you and yours a blessed Thanksgiving and a very joyful holiday season! Sustainability Manager, City of Boca Raton Sustainable Thanksgiving: Tips for Keeping the Feast, But Reducing the Waste Nationwide, an estimated 300+ million pounds of food are wasted on Thanksgiving alone. Reducing even a small slice of that waste locally makes a measurable climate and community impact. Sustainable Holidays: Gifts, Lights, Trees, & Celebrations with a Lighter Footprint Household waste can spike substantially during the holiday season (analyses show roughly a 20–25% increase in household trash in December over other months). Lighting is also a meaningful part of seasonal electricity use — but switching to LEDs cuts holiday lighting energy by ~70–85% compared to incandescent bulbs. Reducing physical waste and utilizing more efficient lighting can make big differences in reducing your holiday footprint. The City's Christmas tree recycling program will run from Dec. 26, 2025 through Jan. 19, 2026. Residents can drop off their “clean” Christmas trees (remove all lights & decorations) at Countess de Hoernle Park (1000 Spanish River Blvd, southern end of the parking lot next to the maintenance area). Recreation Services will pick up the trees and chip them into mulch to be used at the Gumbo Limbo Nature Center. An Otterly Abundant Thanksgiving! On November 2, two playful North American river otters (Lontra canadensis) were spotted in the Lake Worth Drainage District E-3 Canal near the intersection of South Military Trail and Verde Trail South. This species is found throughout the state (where it is the only native otter) and inhabits freshwater rivers, lakes, marshes, and coastal estuaries. The otters tend to avoid heavily urbanized or polluted waterways, so their presence may be a good sign for the E-3 Canal water quality! Adult river otters typically reach 3-4 feet long (with a strong and tapered tail that acts like a rudder when swimming) and weigh 10-25 pounds, though males can reach up to 30 pounds. The two otters viewed in the E-3 were certainly pushing to reach that maximum weight as they made a feast of apple snails from the canal. There were at least a dozen empty shells strewn across the canal bank in the vicinity of the otters. What a delicious and nutritious pre-Thanksgiving meal! This was a fantastic opportunity to be able to view these adorable and inquisitive animals. Be warned, however, otters are highly intelligent and can be aggressive if threatened. They are wild carnivores, so treat them as such and enjoy them safely from a distance if you happen to see them. They will probably be just as interested in seeing you! Update on the Children's Science Explorium Chickee Hut In our last newsletter, you saw the ongoing progress to clear weeds from around the Children’s Science Explorium’s new Chickee hut in preparation for planting a native landscape. On October 28, the vision was completed when a team from the Explorium working with Woodly and Jean from the City’s maintenance team installed over 95 native plants including southern shield ferns, coontie, cocoplum, wild coffee, muhly grass and more! Make sure to stop by frequently and watch as the plants fill in the space, and stay tuned to City outreach to find out about events that will soon be offered in the Chickee hut! Sustainability Heroes Thank you to Nancy and Daphna from Boca Raton Garden Club (BRGC) for refreshing the four planters on the Spanish River Library footbridge. In addition to fresh soil and mulch, new bromeliads were installed and a native coontie was replaced. The planters are a collaboration between BRGC and HABcenter nursery (who supplies the planting materials). These dedicated partners beautify the landscape for all those enjoying the trail around Spanish River Library and Pondhawk Natural Area. Check it out on your next visit and appreciate Nancy and Daphna’s green thumbs! A big thanks to students, teachers, staff and the PTA of Verde Elementary School for collecting over 9,700 wrappers which made up about 84% of the City’s entire collection for Loggerhead Marinelife Center’s Unwrap the Waves candy wrapper recycling program. Thank you for keeping this source of plastic from reaching our ecosystems! (We collected 11,550 wrappers in total this year!) Well done citizen scientists! You can be a Citizen Scientist anytime! At Spanish River Library, stop by the Check Out desk and ask to borrow a Citizen Science Kit. The Citizen Science Kits are designed to help adults and older children participate in the scientific process, to address societal needs and accelerate science, technology and innovation. The kits provide the opportunity to conduct experiments, collect data, interpret results, make new discoveries, and crowdsource. There are kits to investigate various topics including Exploring Biodiversity, Monitoring Water Quality, Measuring Light in the Night, and more. Grab your kit and work as a family to learn something new over Thanksgiving and winter breaks. Are you, or someone you know, going above and beyond for sustainability in the City of Boca Raton? Submit them for the next edition! Email us at sustainability@myboca.us www.myboca.us/sustainability sustainability@myboca.us City of Boca Raton | 201 West Palmetto Park Road | Boca Raton, FL 33432 US Unsubscribe | Update Profile | Constant Contact Data Notice

headline: Holidays in Boca
content: Experience all the holiday fun Recreation Services has to offer during the November and December months.

headline: Discover Something New at Wildflower Park!
content: Wildflower Park | 551 East Palmetto Park Road | Park Hours: 7:00am - 11:00pm This fall and winter, the City of Boca Raton’s Recreation Services Department invites you to experience Wildflower in Bloom, a series of FREE events and activities at Wildflower Park. Enjoy recreation pop-ups, fitness classes, plant giveaways, and more - all set against the stunning backdrop of the Intracoastal Waterway. Pilates | Saturdays | 9amStart your weekend on a healthy note with our free Pilates sessions at Wildflower Park. Held every Saturday morning by the scenic intracoastal, these sessions provide a refreshing and invigorating experience, perfect for setting a positive tone for the days ahead. Beginners or seasoned Pilates are welcome. Please bring your own mat and water bottle. Yoga | Sundays | 9amEmbrace the tranquility of Sunday mornings with our free Yoga sessions at Wildflower Park. These drop-in classes require no registration. Surrounded by the calming atmosphere of the intracoastal, it's a perfect opportunity to unwind and reconnect with yourself. Please bring your own yoga mat and water bottle. Bootcamp | Wednesdays | 5:30pmEnergize your midweek with our free Bootcamp sessions at Wildflower Park on Wednesday afternoons. These workouts are an excellent way to de-stress after a long day at work. Join us by the beautiful intracoastal for a high-energy fitness experience that will leave you feeling revitalized. This is a drop-in class, registration is not required. Please bring your own water bottle. Plant Giveaway | Nov 14 & Dec 12 | 1amJoin the City of Boca Raton's Office of Sustainability for a complimentary plant giveaway! Visit Wildflower Park to collect a native plant to bring home. No registration is necessary, and plants will be distributed on a first-come, first-served basis. Rec Pop-Up Day |TBDJoin the Recreation Services Department for this monthly event, where a different section will be showcased, offering a fun experience for the community. Public Art Boca Centennial Installations | Dec 6Boca Raton’s Public Art program is bringing color, creativity, and conversation to our community with projects like Plastic Poetry, the Reflections of Time Sculpture, and Art on BRiC Walls 2025: Perspective – Beyond the Surface. Keep an eye out for upcoming installations Wildflower Park’s Centennial Legacy Mosaics, and the anticipated return of Mi Casa, Your Casa 2.0 this December. More activities and events coming in 2026! Interested in having your program or class at Wildflower Park? Fill out the Vendor Application! Boca Raton City Hall:201 W Palmetto Park Road Boca Raton, FL 33432

headline: Golfing in Boca Raton
content: Golf News & Updates from the City of Boca Raton | November 2025 Perfect Weather, Perfect Golf in Boca Raton. Sunny skies and mild temperatures make Boca Raton the perfect place to enjoy a round of golf this season. Whether you’re looking to get outdoors or share time with family over the holidays, the City’s two public courses offer something for everyone. Join a league, take a lesson, or just enjoy the greens. The Boca Raton Golf & Racquet Club was proud to host a recent PGA HOPE (Helping Our Patriots Everywhere) clinic, where military veterans celebrated their graduation from the program. PGA HOPE introduces veterans to the game of golf at no cost, helping them build community and enhance their physical, mental, and emotional well-being through the sport. Thank you all for your dedication and service! Reminder: Winter Rates Winter rates at both City courses began November 1, so don’t forget to check the latest pricing when booking your next round. Enjoy great course conditions and plenty of opportunities to get out and play. Boca Raton Golf & Racquet Club Rates Red Reef Family Golf Course Rates Plus, remember a little courtesy goes a long way. Review the City’s Golf Course Code of Ethics for a smooth and enjoyable round. Recent facility upgrades at the Boca Raton Golf & Racquet Club include completed hallway restrooms, which are now open to the public. New ball washers have also been installed on the course. Coming up, on-course restrooms will get a roof replacement, with at least one restroom per nine holes will remain open during construction. Enjoy these improvements on your next round and stay tuned for more! Recent Hole in One Players - Congratulations! Boca Raton Golf & Racquet Club Red Reef Family Golf Course The City's Head Golf Professional Ken Smythe is back with another helpful Golf Tip of the Day. Take a look and improve your skills and game out on the course. New! Using Your Hybrid Club Catch up on our previous Golf Tips: A few fun golf facts to keep you in the know! Did you know Boca Raton averages over 230 sunny days a year? Perfect for teeing off nearly any day — no matter the season. The Old Course at Broken Sound features an incredibly long par-5 hole, stretching nearly 600 yards. It’s a true challenge for any golfer. There are over 38,000 golf courses worldwide, and the U.S. has nearly half of them Walking 18 holes can burn up to 1,500 calories, making golf a great way to stay active while enjoying the outdoors. James Hardie Pro Football Hall of Fame Invitational From March 2–8, 2026, the Old Course at Broken Sound will host the popular PGA TOUR Champions event, featuring top golfers competing for a $2+ million purse. Football legends also join for two days of thrilling on-course action — a must-see week of golf right here in Boca Raton. Learn More. See You Out on the Course 17751 Boca Club Blvd. The par-72 championship 18-hole golf course has tees ranging from 5,000 to 6,600 yards, and provides a challenge for all levels including a par 5 finishing hole with a beautiful island green. Alan C. Alford Red Reef The 9-hole, 1,357-yard course provides breathtaking views of both the Intracoastal Waterway and Atlantic Ocean and has holes ranging from 64 to 227 yards in length. The Alan C. Alford Red Reef Family Golf Course is funded in part by the Greater Boca Raton Beach & Park District.
